data.text:
Elizabeth had several important character traits which were her strengths.

❖ She was . This meant she could have her choice of rather than be controlled by a foreign husband.

❖ She was cautious. She understood the balance needed to maintain her , particularly regarding the rivalry between Protestants and Catholics.

❖ She was an intelligent and well-educated queen. She spoke foreign languages, enjoyed theatre and music, and shrewdly rewarded loyalty to those who served her.

❖ She was dominant. She was always ready to assert her power and refused to be controlled by anyone.

❖ She was a skilful self-publicist. She worked hard to create the right image and ensured her presented her well.

Elizabeth had a traumatic childhood that shaped her character as queen.

❖ Elizabeth's father, Henry VIII, divorced her mother, Anne Boleyn, accusing her of adultery. Boleyn was eventually executed.

❖ Henry VIII married his third wife, Jane Seymour, only 11 days after Anne Boleyn was executed.

❖ Elizabeth was estranged from her father, Henry VIII for some of her childhood.

❖ When Elizabeth's half-sister, Mary, became queen she imprisoned Elizabeth in the Tower of London and accused her of supporting a against her.

Elizabeth faced a number of problems in 1558.

❖ She was left with of Â£300,000 by Mary I, following an expensive war with France.

❖ She was female and some people feared England would be seen as a weak country because most others at the time, such as Spain, were ruled by men.

❖ Elizabeth had been declared following her mother's execution. Many saw her as an illegitimate daughter from an unlawful marriage, and not the rightful Queen of England.

❖ Religion was a huge problem. The country had switched from Catholicism to Protestantism and then back again since Henry VIII's death in 1547. It was a religious rollercoaster, causing conflict and confusion.

❖ There were threats from Catholics. Many were opposed to Elizabeth's Religious Settlement and wanted her cousin, Mary, Queen of Scots, on

❖ The government needed more money but Elizabeth inherited a country riddled with . Increased taxation would be an unpopular and dangerous move.

Marriage was a problem for Elizabeth. As a queen in the 16th century, she was expected to marry and have children. However, during this time men had more authority than women. Elizabeth did not want to to the authority of a husband. Although she had many , she never married.

England had been at war with France intermittently since 1522 and it had been costly. When Elizabeth came to in 1558, she inherited a Â£300,000 from Henry VIII and Mary I. She needed to find a solution to this hole in the country's finances.

As well as inheriting a considerable , Elizabeth needed to reduce government spending. She did this by reducing her own household spending and selling off land belonging to the Crown. This took 20 years, but by 1585 she had paid off the debt and built a surplus of Â£300,000.
